'''William H. Goetzmann''' (July 20, 1930 – September 7, 2010) was an American historian and emeritus professor in the American Studies and American Civilization Programs at the [[University of Texas at Austin]]. He attended [[Yale University]] as a graduate student and was friends with [[Tom Wolfe]] while there. His work on the American West won him the highest prizes for historians, the Parkman Prize and the Pulitzer Prize. He has written and published extensively on American philosophy, American political history, and the American arts. An advocate for the importance of history as a public discussion, he has served in various capacities in television and film production, notably for [[PBS]]. He was most recently the Jack S. Blanton, Sr., Chair Emeritus in History and American Studies. His last book published during his lifetime was ''Beyond the Revolution: A History of American Thought From [[Thomas Paine|Paine]] to Pragmatism'' (2009). ==Biography== William H. Goetzmann was born in Washington and raised in the American Midwest, notably in St. Paul, Minnesota, where his family once rented an apartment previously occupied by the bank robber [[John Dillinger]].Jeff Salamon, "William H. Goetzmann Discusses "Beyond the Revolution," ''Austin American-Statesman'', April 12, 2009 , [http://www.statesman.com/life/content/life/stories/books/04/12/0412goetzmann.html] The Dillinger-apartment experience was one of many that drew him to the study of history as a dramatic narrative populated by colorful individuals and sweeping movements. Educated at [[Yale University]] where he received BA and Ph.D. degrees, he taught at Yale from 1955 to 1964, with his interest in the history of the West sparked by the historian [[Howard R. Lamar]]. He then moved to [[The University of Texas at Austin]] to develop its fledgling American Studies and American Civilization Programs. His early writing concerned American diplomacy and American expansionism; in 1966, Alfred A. Knopf published his ''Exploration and Empire: The Explorer and the Scientist in the Winning of the American West'', which rapidly won the two most prestigious prizes in American historical writing, the Parkman Prize and the Pulitzer Prize. Over the next 5 decades, he published widely, establishing himself as one of the nation's premiere historians, and ranging widely among intellectual history, cultural history, art history, history of science, and history of philosophy.
A devoted and influential teacher, he was mentor to [[MacArthur Fellows Program|MacArthur "Genius Award"]] winner [[Stephen J. Pyne]], design historian [[Jeffrey Meikle]], historian of photography and cultural historian [[Peter Bacon Hales]], novelist and cultural historian [[Kay Sloan]], and many others. Goetzmann died of congestive heart failure in Austin, Texas. He was survived by his wife, Mewes Goetzmann, sons William N., of New Haven, and Stephen R. Goetzmann of Dallas; a daughter, Anne Goetzmann Kelley of Austin; and five grandchildren.Grimes, William, [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/12/arts/12goetzmann.html?hpw "William H. Goetzmann, Pulitzer-Winning Historian, Dies at 80"], ''The New York Times'', September 11, 2010. Retrieved 2010-09-12. ==Awards== *1967 [[Francis Parkman Prize]] and [[1967 Pulitzer Prize]] for History, both for ''Exploration and Empire'' ==Partial bibliography== *''Army Exploration in the American West, 1803-1863''. Yale University Press, 1959. *''When the Eagle Screamed: The Romantic Horizon in American Expansionism, 1800-1860''. John Wiley, 1966. *''[[Exploration and Empire: The Explorer and the Scientist in the Winning of the American West]]''. Alfred A. Knopf, 1966.{{cite web|title=Exploration and Empire: The Explorer and the Scientist in the Winning of the American West|url=http://siarchives.si.edu/collections/siris_sic_2769|publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution Archives]]|accessdate=11 April 2012}} *''American [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|Hegelians]]: an Intellectual Episode in the History of Western America'', ed. Alfred A. Knopf, 1973. *''The West as Romantic Horizon''. [[Joslyn Art Museum]] and University of Nebraska Press, 1981. *''New Lands, New Men: America and the Second Great Age of Discovery''. Viking Press, 1986. *''The West of the Imagination'' (with William N. Goetzmann). Norton Press, 1986. *[[Saint Patrick's Battalion#References|George Ballentine]]’s ''Autobiography of an English Soldier in the United States Army'' (1986), ed. *''The First Americans: Photographs From the [[Library of Congress]]''. Starwood Publications, 1991. *Gen. [[Samuel Chamberlain]]’s ''My Confession: Recollections of a Rogue'' (1996), ed. *''Beyond the Revolution: A History of American Thought From Paine to Pragmatism''. Basic Books, 2009. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{C-SPAN|William Goetzmann}} *{{Find a Grave}} {{PulitzerPrize HistoryAuthors 1951–1975}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Goetzmann, William H.}} [[Category:Pulitzer Prize for History winners]] [[Category:Harvard University faculty]] [[Category:University of Texas at Austin faculty]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:American historians of philosophy]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]]

{{For|those of a similar name|Norman Fisher (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox religious biography |background = #FFD068 |name = Zoketsu Norman Fischer |image= Norman Fischer 3.jpg |caption = |alias = |dharma name = |birth_date = c. 1946 |birth_place = [[Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania]], [[United States]] |death_date = |death_place = |nationality = [[United States|American]] |religion = [[Zen Buddhism]] |school = [[Sōtō]] |lineage = [[Shunryu Suzuki]] |title = [[Rōshi|Roshi]] |location = Everyday Zen Foundation |education = [[University of Iowa]]
[[University of California, Berkeley]]
[[Graduate Theological Union]] |teacher = |reincarnation of = |predecessor = [[Sojun Mel Weitsman]] |successor = |students = |spouse = Kathie Fischer |children = Aron and Noah (twins) |website = [http://www.everydayzen.org www.everydayzen.org]
[http://www.bellinghamzen.org www.bellinghamzen.org] }} '''Zoketsu Norman Fischer''' is an American poet, writer, and [[Sōtō|Soto Zen]] priest, teaching and practicing in the lineage of [[Shunryū Suzuki|Shunryu Suzuki]].{{Cite web|url=https://static1.squarespace.com/static/52a23ac8e4b05fd98a111e34/t/52a88d97e4b025722daf9700/1386778007039/2012Sept.Fischer.pdf|title=Jewish Buddhist Encounters|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} He is a [[Dharma heir]] of [[Mel Weitsman|Sojun Mel Weitsman]], from whom he received Dharma transmission in 1988. Fischer served as co-abbot of the [[San Francisco Zen Center]] from 1995–2000, after which he founded the Everyday Zen Foundation in 2000, a network of Buddhist practice group and related projects in Canada, the United States and Mexico.{{Cite web|url=http://www.everydayzen.org/about-everyday-zen/teachers/|title=Everyday Zen :: Teachers|website=www.everydayzen.org|language=en|access-date=2017-06-22}} Fischer has published more than twenty-five books of poetry and non-fiction, as well as numerous poems, essays and articles in Buddhist magazines and poetry journals.{{Cite web|url=http://www.normanfischer.org/biography/|title=Biography|website=Norman Fischer Books|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-21}} == Early life and education == Norman Fischer was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family in [[Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania]] in 1946, and was raised in [[Pittston, Pennsylvania]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lQrFusMMVH0C&pg=PA257&lpg=PA257&dq=Pittston+Pennsylvania+norman+fischer&source=bl&ots=oQnXj-nfRq&sig=saSyursyEyhcoiO4fRPxZzsCNCw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiynMKw8M3UAhVP-GMKHRc2DeoQ6AEISTAF#v=onepage&q=Pittston%20Pennsylvania%20norman%20fischer&f=false|title=The Three-Pound Enigma: The Human Brain and the Quest to Unlock Its Mysteries|last=Moffett|first=Shannon|date=2006-01-20|publisher=Algonquin Books|isbn=9781565128903|language=en}} As a child he attended services with his parents at a [[Conservative]] [[synagogue]].{{cite book |last=Loundon |first=Sumi |title=The Buddha's Apprentices: More Voices of Young Buddhists |publisher=Wisdom Publications |year=2006 |location=Boston |pages=125–130 |url =https://books.google.com/books?id=CdCBgXgnXukC&pg=PA125 |isbn=086171332X}} He received a B.A. from [[Colgate University]], where he studied religion, philosophy, and literature, an M.F.A. in poetry from the [[Iowa Writers' Workshop]] at the [[University of Iowa]], and an M.A. in history and phenomenology of religion at the [[University of California, Berkeley]], and the [[Graduate Theological Union]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.normanfischer.org/reviews-interviews-all/john-wright-language-and-emptiness-an-interview-with-norman-fischer|title=Language and emptiness: John Wright interviews Norman Fischer|work=Norman Fischer Books|access-date=2017-06-21|language=en-US}} == Religious practice == === Zen training, service and teaching === From 1970 through 1976, Fischer trained at the [[Berkeley Zen Center]], a temple in the lineage of [[Shunryū Suzuki|Shunryu Suzuki]], under the guidance of [[Mel Weitsman|Sojun Mel Weitsman]]. In 1976, he and his wife moved to [[Tassajara Zen Mountain Center|Tassajara]], a training monastery near [[Big Sur]], where they lived as residential monastics for five years. In 1980, they were both ordained as Zen priests by [[Zentatsu Richard Baker]], from whom Fischer received the dharma name Zoketsu Rinsho. In 1981, they moved to [[Green Gulch Farm Zen Center]] in [[Marin County, California]], where Fischer served in various monastic positions including Director, Tanto (Head of Practice), and Co-Abbot from 1981 to 2000. During that time, in 1988, he received [[Dharma transmission]] from his longtime teacher, Sojun Mel Weitsman.[http://www.sfzc.org/zc/display.asp?catid=1,5&pageid=426 San Francisco Zen Center: Lineage] From 1995 to 2000, Fischer served as co-abbot of the [[San Francisco Zen Center]] (SFZC), first with Sojun Mel Weitsman, and then with Zenkei [[Blanche Hartman]].{{cite book |last=Prebish |first=Charles S. |author2=Martin Baumann |title =Westward Dharma: Buddhism Beyond Asia |publisher=University of California Press |year =2002 |location=Berkeley |pages =226 |oclc=48871649 |isbn=0520226259}} During his abbacy, Fischer supported the research, drafting and formal institution of a women’s lineage chant, alongside the traditional men’s lineage chant, during services. Later, with poet and translator [[Peter Levitt]], he supported the drafting of an official women’s lineage paper—the first female lineage document in the history of any major world religion—which traces the line of female practitioners from the Buddha’s time to the present and recognizes the important historical role of the Zen women ancestors.{{Cite news|url=https://tricycle.org/magazine/roused-dream/|title=Roused from a Dream|last=Fowles|first=Mary|work=Tricycle|access-date=2017-06-22|language=en-US}} As a senior Dharma teacher, Fischer continues to participate at the San Francisco Zen Center and its affiliate temples, giving talks and leading practice events. In 2000, he founded the Everyday Zen Foundation, which has practice groups in Canada, the United States and Mexico.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfzc.org/city-center/zen-meditation-practice/teachers/guest-teachers-lecturers/zoketsu-norman-fischer-senior-dharma-teacher|title=Zoketsu Norman Fischer (Senior Dharma Teacher) {{!}} San Francisco Zen Center|website=www.sfzc.org|language=en|access-date=2017-06-22}} Fischer has also integrated Buddhist contemplative practices in business, law, and education—specifically for hospice workers, software engineers, and conflict resolution specialists. In 1987, Fischer founded (among others) the [[Zen Hospice Project]] at the San Francisco Zen Center, for which he served as board chair for over 20 years, and is now emeritus chair.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ramdass.org/norman-fischer/|title=RamDass: Norman Fischer|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} He is also a faculty member of the Metta Institute, a training institute for hospice caregivers.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mettainstitute.org/EOLfaculty.html|title=Metta : EOL Faculty|website=www.mettainstitute.org|access-date=2017-06-22}} In 2007, he developed (along with [[Chade-Meng Tan]], Mirabai Bush, Daniel Golemen and [[Jon Kabat-Zinn]]) the course on mindfulness and emotional intelligence, [[Search Inside Yourself Leadership Institute|“Search Inside Yourself”]],{{Cite news|url=http://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/googles-chade-meng-tan-wants-you-to-search-inside-yourself-for-inner-and-world-peace/|title=Google's Chade-Meng Tan Wants You to Search Inside Yourself for Inner (and World) Peace - Knowledge@Wharton|work=Knowledge@Wharton|access-date=2017-06-22|language=en-US}} which was originally taught at Google’s program for employees, and has now been taught to over 20,000 people in more than 100 cities.{{Cite web|url=https://siyli.org/about|title=siyli.org {{!}} About|date=2017-06-21|website=siyli.org|language=en-us|access-date=2017-06-22}} Fischer is currently involved with conflict resolution work at Gary Friedman and Jack Himmelstein’s [http://understandinginconflict.org/ Center for Understanding in Conflict], where he trains conflict resolution professionals.{{Cite web|url=http://understandinginconflict.org/our-trainers/|title=Our Trainers {{!}} The Center for Understanding in Conflict|website=understandinginconflict.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-22}} He has also consulted with [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] chaplains about incorporating Zen practices into their work.{{Cite news|url=https://mountainx.com/arts/art-news/zen_judaism/|title=Zen Judaism|work=Mountain Xpress|access-date=2017-06-22|language=en-US}} He has taught and lectured at [[Harvard University|Harvard]], [[Yale University|Yale]], [[Brown University|Brown]] and [[Stanford University|Stanford]] universities{{Cite web|url=http://ptreyesbooks.com/events/norman-fischer-0|title=Norman Fischer|last=uw|date=2016-01-03|website=Point Reyes Books|language=en|access-date=2017-06-22}} and in 2014, he gave the baccalaureate address at Stanford University.{{Cite news|url=http://news.stanford.edu/news/2014/june/fischer-baccalaureate-text-061414.html|title=Prepared text of Zoketsu Norman Fischer's Baccalaureate address|work=Stanford University|access-date=2017-06-22|language=en}}  He has also served as mentor to teenage boys; this experience is chronicled in his book ''Taking Our Places: The Buddhist Path to Truly Growing Up'' ([[HarperOne]], 2003).{{Cite news|url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-06-050551-6|title=Book Review: Taking Our Places: The Buddhist Path to Truly Growing Up by Norman Fischer, Author HarperOne $23.95 (208p)|ISBN=978-0-06-050551-6|work=PublishersWeekly.com|access-date=2017-06-22|language=en}} Fischer also teaches Zen workshops and retreats on the importance of compassion practice, as modeled in his book, ''Training in Compassion: Zen Teachings on the Practice of Lojong'' ([[Shambhala Publications|Shambhala]], 2013).{{Citation|last=Meditation|first=Seattle Insight|title=Training in Compassion: Zen Teachings on the Practice of Lojong|date=2013-09-11|url=https://vimeo.com/74347362|accessdate=2017-06-22}} This was the subject of a Spring 2016 online course taught by Fischer, and offered through [[Tricycle Magazine]], in collaboration with San Francisco Zen Center.{{Cite web|url=http://www.normanfischer.org/readings-workshops/2016/3/7/tricycle-online-courses-training-in-compassion|title=Tricycle Online Courses: Training in Compassion|website=Norman Fischer Books|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-22}} === Interreligious dialogue === Fischer is a proponent of [[interreligious dialogue]] between the worlds' religions, stating:
 "I feel that in our period it is the challenge of religious traditions to do something more than simply reassert and reinterpret their faiths, hoping for loyal adherents to what they perceive to be the true doctrine. Looking back at the last century, with its devastating wars and holocausts and the shock of ecological vulnerability, I have the sense that religious traditions must now have a wider mission, and it is in the recognition of this mission, I believe, that interreligious dialogue becomes something not only polite and interesting, but also essential." {{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/47136534|title=Purity of heart and contemplation : a monastic dialogue between Christian and Asian traditions|last=1931-|first=Barnhart, Bruno,|last2=Yuese.|first2=Huang,|date=2001|publisher=Continuum|isbn=082641348X|oclc=47136534}}
He currently sits on the Board of World Religious Leaders for the [[Elijah Interfaith Institute]], an interreligious dialogue organization.{{Cite news|url=http://elijah-interfaith.org/world-religious-leaders-activity/the-elijah-board-of-world-religious-leaders/buddhist-leaders|title=Buddhist Leaders|date=2015-04-27|work=Elijah Interfaith|access-date=2017-06-27|language=en-US}} In July 1996, he attended a five-day meeting between members of different religions held at [[Abbey of Our Lady of Gethsemani|The Abbey of Our Lady of Gethsemani]] in Trappist, Kentucky, where he gave a talk about [[Dōgen|Dogen]], [[zazen]], and the importance of religions coming together—despite their different philosophies—to serve humanity.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/746900315|title=The Gethsemani encounter : a dialogue on the spiritual life by Buddhist and Christian monastics|last=1943-|first=Mitchell, Donald W. (Donald William),|last2=1942-|first2=Wiseman, James A.,|date=1997|publisher=Continuum|isbn=0826411657|oclc=746900315}} Fischer has participated in interreligious pilgrimages with Father [[Laurence Freeman]] OSB and the [[Dalai Lama]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.beliefnet.com/faiths/buddhism/2000/09/a-funny-thing-happened-on-the-way-to-the-stupa.aspx|title=A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Stupa|website=www.beliefnet.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-27}} Fischer has been active in the [[Jewish meditation]] movement since the 1990s, working at first with Rabbi Alan Lew, and now with rabbis and Jewish meditation teachers from around the world.{{Cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/religionandethics/2010/06/25/june-25-2010-norman-fischer-on-meditation/6533/|title=June 25, 2010 ~ Norman Fischer on Meditation {{!}} June 25, 2010 {{!}} Religion & Ethics NewsWeekly {{!}} PBS|date=2010-06-25|work=Religion & Ethics NewsWeekly|access-date=2017-06-27|language=en-US}} In January 2000, he and Rabbi Lew founded Makor Or, a Jewish Meditation Center in San Francisco, which Fischer now continues to direct, in the wake of Rabbi Lew’s 2009 death.{{Cite web|url=https://www.jccsf.org/adult/adult-classes/makor-or-jewish-meditation/|title=JCCSF - Makor Or: Jewish Meditation|website=www.jccsf.org|access-date=2017-06-27}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.jweekly.com/2001/06/08/meditation-deepens-judaism-for-makor-or-participants/|title=Meditation deepens Judaism for Makor Or participants|last=admin|date=2001-06-08|website=J.|access-date=2017-06-27}} Fischer has written about the concept of [[God]] being integral to [[Judaism]] and many other religions. In his book ''Opening to You: Zen-Inspired Translations of the Psalms'' ([[Viking Press|Viking]], 2002), Fischer replaced the words "God", "King", and "Lord" with the word "You." He explains:
"For many of the religious seekers I encounter, the word God has been all but emptied of its spiritual power. The relationship to God that is charted out in the Psalms is a stormy one, co-dependent, passionate, confusing, loyal, petulant, sometimes even manipulative. I wanted to find a way to approach these poems so as to emphasize the relational aspect, while avoiding the major distancing pitfalls that words like God, King, Lord and so on create."{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/living/article/Buddhist-translation-of-biblical-Psalms-2772601.php|title='Buddhist' translation of biblical Psalms|work=SFGate|access-date=2017-06-27}}
== Writing == === Poetry === During Fischer’s years at The Iowa Writers’ Workshop, he met poets associated with the [[Language poets|L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E poetry movement]] of the seventies and eighties.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thezensite.com/ZenEssays/Miscellaneous/Language_and_Emptiness.html|title=thezensite:Language and emptiness: An interview with Norman Fischer|website=www.thezensite.com|access-date=2017-06-27}} After receiving his MFA in poetry from the University of Iowa{{Cite news|url=http://poetry.arizona.edu/people/norman-fischer|title=Norman Fischer|date=2015-01-28|work=Poetry Center|access-date=2017-06-27|language=en}} in 1970, he moved to San Francisco where he remained associated with the movement, writing language-centered avant-garde poetry with a spiritual bent and publishing his first poems in 1979. His first collection ''Like a Walk Through a Park'' (Open Books, 1980) comprises poems written at Tassajara Zen Mountain Monastery, where he was in residence with poets [[Jane Hirshfield]] and [[Philip Whalen]]. After Whalen’s death in 2003, Fischer became his literary executor.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems-and-poets/poets/detail/norman-fischer|title=Norman Fischer|date=2017-06-20|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|access-date=2017-06-21}} Fischer has since published over fifteen volumes of poetry.{{Cite web|url=http://www.normanfischer.org/books-of-poetry/|title=Books of Poetry|website=Norman Fischer Books|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-27}} His poetry has been published in literary magazines such as ''Talisman'', ''Jacket,'' ''Mag City, Fracture, Tinfish, Bezoar, Periodics, Bombay Gin, Raddle Moon, Gallery Works, Crayon'', and ''Antenym,'' among others, and anthologized in ''The Wisdom Anthology of North American Poetry,'' and ''Basta Azzez enough''. [[Charles Bernstein]] has called Fischer’s poetry “illuminating and essential”{{Cite news|url=https://www.upaya.org/2015/10/norman-fischer-to-share-from-new-book-in-dharma-talk-tomorrow/|title=Norman Fischer to Share From New Book in Dharma Talk Tomorrow - Upaya Zen Center|date=2015-10-13|work=Upaya Zen Center|access-date=2017-06-27|language=en-US}} and [[Ron Silliman]] says “nobody gives more completely of himself in the act of writing than Norman Fischer...I am in awe of this gift.”{{Cite news|url=http://www.normanfischer.org/books-poetry/the-strugglers|title=The Strugglers|work=Norman Fischer Books|access-date=2017-06-27|language=en-US}} Fischer is a founding board member of Poets in Need, an organization that grants emergency funds to poets in financial distress. === Non-fiction === Fischer has written nine books on Zen,{{Cite web|url=http://www.normanfischer.org/books-on-zen/|title=Books on Zen|website=Norman Fischer Books|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-27}} and numerous essays and books on writing, poetry, and spirituality. His essays have been published in magazines such as ''Buddhadharma'', ''Tricycle'' and ''[[Shambhala Sun]]'', and in collections such as ''Radical Poetics and Secular Jewish Culture'' ([[University of Alabama Press]], 2010) and ''The Best Buddhist Writing'' (Shambhala Sun). == Personal life == Fischer lives in [[Muir Beach, California]] with his wife Kathie, a retired middle school science teacher and ordained Zen priest. In 2012, Kathie received dharma transmission from Sojun Mel Weitzman, and since her retirement from teaching in 2016, has been co-leading Zen workshops and retreats with Norman.{{Cite web|url=https://brooklynzen.org/event/2015/2/15/family-practice-with-kathie-fischer/|title=Family Practice with Norman and Kathie Fischer, Feb. 15th {{!}} Brooklyn Zen Center|website=brooklynzen.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-06-27}} They have twin sons, Aron and Noah, and three grandchildren.{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2003/06/15/LV142971.DTL|title=Father, Buddhist are one and the same: Writer finds new truth through parenting role|last=Lattin|first=Don|date=2003-06-15|publisher=[[SFGate]]|accessdate=2008-02-16}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.whiteheronsangha.org/event-2178409|title=White Heron Sangha - "Imagination" - A Weekend Nonresidential Retreat with Norman and Kathie Fischer|website=www.whiteheronsangha.org|language=en|access-date=2017-06-27}} Aron Fischer is a New York attorney,{{Cite news|url=https://www.pbwt.com/aron-fischer/|title=Biography {{!}} Aron Fischer|work=Patterson Belknap Webb & Tyler LLP|access-date=2017-06-27|language=en-US}} and Noah Fischer, also based in New York,
